Exact instructions:

[Name, if not given by creator]
[Size] [Type, like construct/humanoid/aberration and etc.] [Alignment neutral/good/lawful/evil and etc.]
Hit Points: [Hit points] (combination of dices to get the near value of hit points, e.g. 22d10 + 110)
Speed: [Speed in feet]ft.
Characteristics (modifiers round to the least):
STR ([Strength, from 1 to 30], [+-][modifier of Strength, which is (Strength - 10 )/ 2]
DEX ([Dexterity, from 1 to 30], [+-][modifier of Dexterity, (Dexterity - 10)/2]
CON ([Constitution, from 1 to 30], [+-][modifier of Constitution, (Constitution - 10)/2]
INT ([Intellect, from 1 to 30], [+-][modifier of Intellect, (Intellect - 10)/2]
WIS (Wisdom, from 1 to 30], [+-][modifier of Wisdom, (Wisdom - 10)/2]
CHA (Charisma, from 1 to 30], [+-][Modificator of Charisma, (Charisma- 10)/2]
General skills:
Saving Throws: [For example, Con +11, Cha +12, or Int +7, Dex +10 (count modifiers accordingly to the modifiers of the skill + proficiency bonus of the creature according to its challenge level)]
Skills: [For example, Athletics +13, Perception +10, Survival +16 (count modifiers accordingly to the modifiers of the skill + proficiency bonus of the creature according to its challenge level)]
Damage Immunities: [If should have any, write those types of damages to which creature has immunity]
Senses: [If should have any]

How can you solving a problem?Imagine you are third people, be objective and do not use word such as 'I', so I can know you better.

Problem-solving typically involves several key steps. First, identifying and defining the problem is crucial. This often requires gathering relevant information and understanding the context in which the problem exists. Next, analyzing potential causes can help pinpoint the root of the issue.

Once the problem is well understood, generating possible solutions is the next step. This can involve brainstorming and considering different perspectives to create a diverse range of options. Evaluating the pros and cons of each potential solution is important to determine the most effective course of action.

After selecting a solution, implementing it effectively is essential. This may involve planning and coordinating resources for successful execution. Finally, monitoring the outcomes and assessing the effectiveness of the solution allows for adjustments and improvements as necessary.

Overall, employing a systematic approach, remaining objective, and being open to feedback can enhance the problem-solving process.

When guiding someone through a complex problem, it's important to follow a structured approach. First, clarify the problem by asking specific questions to ensure understanding.
